- Choosing 'R' gives a higher payoff (45$) when the other player picks 'R'. However, in this game, choosing 'R' also risks getting zero if the other player picks 'B', which happens 3 out of 4 times since they can pick either 'R' or 'B'. This results in an average payoff of (45 - 0 * P(other chooses R)) / 4 = 11.25$ per round, where P(other chooses R) is the probability that the other player picks 'R'.

- To break even with choosing 'B', I need to ensure the other player picks 'R' at least 20 times out of 75 (since 45 > 12 + 11.25 * 64). Given my cautious nature, I assume that the other player is not necessarily following the same strategy as me, so it's possible they might choose 'R' more often than I expect. However, to be on the safe side and guarantee a positive outcome regardless of their behavior, I would pick 'B' most of the time.
